abstracts.cdata!:
The Borrower requested cancellation of
            this loan to be effective December 31, 2000, with about 5.2
            percent of the original loan amount having been disbursed,
            due to a deteriorated implementation environment which
            resulted from widespread social unrest. Other factors
            affecting implementation were that inherent complexities in
            the geographic setting, logistical framework, institutional
            capacity, and project design provided a formidable challenge
            to management at the outset. In terms of the physical,
            financial, and human resources capacity alone, the
            management workload aspects were underestimated and caused
            immediate deficiencies in project performance. The project
            never achieved a level of sustainable or effective momemtum,
            and would have needed intensive professional support to
            off-set low implementation capacity. Among the lessons to be
            learned are that 1) Complex projects with geographically
            dispersed characteristics could be more successfully
            implemented at a more decentralized level; 2) Project
            management and supervision decisions taken by the Bank and
            clients require corporate continuity and consistency in
            approach to assist project performance while allowing for a
            transition to full implementation momentum; and 3)
            Post-conflict reviews and/or assessments of needs and sector
            rehabilitation potential would provide longer term planning
            benefit to the client and the Bank for loan projects closed
            due to civil unrest.

5083290.trustfund: TF037547-INDONESIA - MALUKU REGIONAL DEVELOPMENT,TF022782-PHRD-EASTERN ISLANDS REGIONAL DEV.I
5083290.majtheme: Financial and private sector development,Rural development

abstracts.cdata!:
The objective of the Maluku Regional
            Development Project for Indonesia is to alleviate poverty in
            rural and coastal areas of Maluku and generate economic
            growth. This project has five components. The first expands,
            intensifies, and rehabilitates tree crops on land owned by
            low income households. It procures seed stock; trains farmer
            seed growers on nursery methods for tree crops; trains
            farmers in controlling coconut and coffee diseases and pests
            and in intercropping techniques; and trains staff in disease
            and pest control, farming systems development and extension
            methods, management information systems, and other
            specialized areas. The second component comprises community
            development for infrastructure and income generation,
            focusing on agricultural production, post-harvesting
            processing, fisheries-related activities, and women's
            income-earning activities. It trains facilitators to assist
            community participants in planning, developing and
            implementing proposals. The third component funds support
            services for agriculture and fisheries such as processing
            and marketing, animal health and extension, technology
            diffusion and demonstrations, fisheries and marine support,
            and seed multiplication for irrigated agriculture. The
            fourth component improves docks for sea transportation and
            on-shore (storage) facilities. The fifth component provides
            training, technical assistance, and equipment to strengthen
            the capacity of agencies to manage, coordinate, monitor, and
            evaluate projects.
